B000002P5R|3.0|I don't quite agree with the previous review; i think this record lacks of something that i'm going to try to describe :  1 - the less important thing : the cover : in my opinion, this cover is awful and should fit better as the poster of a summer blockbuster sience fiction film.  2 - the sound of the music : i'm used to listening the four first records of Hendrix (i include here the 'Band Of Gypsys), and when i compared the sound of 'First Rays' with these records i can't help feeling there is something strange unnatural? in the sound of 'First rays'; Hendrix's sound is a sort of trademark in 'Are you Experienced' 'Axis' 'Electric Ladyland' and 'Band of Gypsys', here this trademark sound is somewhat lacking, absent, the sound seems too polished whereas a particularity of the sound of Hendrix in the records aforementioned is its rawness, i almost would say 'its crudeness'; there isn't enough both blues and psychedelia on this CD, a good blues track like 'It's too bad' with Larry Young would have been welcomed.  3 - The beginning of the record : i absolutely don't know which were the intentions of Hendrix with this record but in my opinion, i would have preferred that the record starts with an experimental instrumental track as this is the case for 'Axis' and 'Electric Ladyland', a sort of 'trademark' in the way by which Hendrix was beginning his records; in plus, and here again, in accordance with my tastes, i don't like at all the instrumental 'Beginnings' and i think there is a lot of better instrumentals of Hendrix than this one; 'Beginnings' mustn't be confused with the excellent 'Jam Back at The House' performed at Woodstock, what remains of 'Jam Back At The House' on 'Beginnings' is very basic.   4 - The choice, selection of the songs : not all the tracks are bad : Angel (i feel that the version on South Saturn Delta is by far my favorite), Freedom (good guitar parts, particularly by the end of the song, but personally i find the Isle of Wight version of thissong largely superior to this one), 'Ezy Rider' is a good song but here too i have got a problem with the mixes, i have been listening to an another version of this track with more psychedelia which is better; the title song 'Hey Baby (New rising sun)' is very promising, but it seems to be unfinished, the same can be said for 'Drifting', a good ballad - the second half of 'Drifting' is like a white page that James Marshall Hendrix surely would have completed had he lived enough for doing it; furthermore, i don't like the songs 'Room Full Of Mirror' or 'Dolly dagger' but perhaps there is better versions of these songs on other cd - i find 'Dolly Dagger' a little bit overrated and too radio-friendly for my taste, but here too, i must say i have been listening to a better version of this song on the Isle of Wight; 'Belly button Window' is an interesting minimalist blues song which reminds me of 'Up from the skies' on 'Axis' since the both songs share singing/guitar wah-wah pedal response; 'Izabella' is a good funky track with short guitar riff in the style of 'Little Miss Lover' on 'Axis' ( there is a much better version of this song with more psychedelia and by far finer than this one on the six CD box 'Astro Man', i don't know whether this box is still available).      As a result : this is not a classic, obviously, 'First Rays' is not on the same level and is inferior to 'Are You Experienced', 'Axis', 'Electric ladyland' (Electric Ladyland is far more achieved than this CD) and 'Band Of Gypsys; some good tracks aforementioned however make me give this record three stars, but it is difficult to me to give more in regard to the flaws i review above.

The plot develops very quickly but there are some gaping holes that make the film seem a bit unrealistic.  The sub titles are helpful because if you are unfamiliar with Jamaican patios the movie will be hard to follow.  However, the sub titles don't include all the dialogue.   In my opinion this is will be a long time cult favorite. <br />

Each year there are books that are on my `must read to the kids' list and The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe is high on that list. <br /> <br />C.S. has done an incredible job in creating a timeless journey to an amazing fantasy land that kids just love!  The struggle between good and evil has prompted many discussions after reading the book.  I'm a fan, and each year the series prompts many of my students to go find the box set.  I think the series is a must read; for kids of all ages. <br /> <br />I highly recommend this book, but beware there is some violence in the book, but again I think that handled properly even 3rd graders can discuss the perils of Good and Evil. <br /> <br />Find the Series, but please read \\"The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe\\" first the way C.S. Lewis originally intended it to be read.  Here's the order I was taught.  Yes, \\"the old way\\" to read the stories is much better in my opinion. <br /> <br />1. Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe <br />2. Prince Caspian  <br />3. Voyage of the Dawn Treader  <br />4. The Silver Chair <br />5. Horse and His Boy <br />6. Magicians Nephew <br />7. The Last Battle <br />
B0007GAEW6|4.0|The Mars Volta is an unlikely success. Listening to old ATDI, I could scarcely guess that Omar's talent was so multifaceted, or Cedric's voice so potentially enthralling. Frances The Mute continues the impressive tradition that De-Loused started, while veering off in unimaginable and enticing directions. Frances feels much more organic than de-loused. There are only five main tracks, and each track develops and grows in a fashion that seems to defy order to an even greater extent than the De-Loused tracks. What you loved about De-Loused is back, along with what you didn't care for. Omar's guitar maneuverings are delicious on Frances, especially on Cygnus and Cassandra. John Frusciante appears again on Frances and makes a very un-John Frusciante move by providing explosive solos for L'via. The indulgence everyone griped about on De-Loused returns on FTM, this time considerably amplified. There is an extended period of silence on Cassandra, and Miranda is preempted by five minutes of birds chirping (think of the beginning of televators, times five). Also, the lyrics of Frances are as uncomprehensible as those of its predecessor, outlining a dark, proggy plot what one cannot hope to fathom. If you were put off by the indulgences of The Mars Volta on De-Loused, you probably won't like this album. However, like their breakout recording, Frances counterbalances the group's excessive white-noise and uber-complicated lyrics with exceptional musical material. L'via is unbelievably listenable: it veers between tight, rhythmic, super-funk and cool, melodica salsa. Cassandra is epochal: 32 minutes long, pulse quickening the whole way. Cedric beautifully narrates the whole album, often in Spanish (his english may as well be spanish, it's unlikely that anyone will understand it).  Once again, The Mars Volta flatly reject the notion that gifted musicians can't make a rock album that reaches a wide audience. Omar and Cedric's sense of rhythm, experimentation and funk put them at alevel that few other performers could ever hope to touch. Anyone who makes a comparison to Rush and Yes is being small-minded. The artistry that The Mars Volta possess is somehting unparalleled by any other cosmic prog band. They dare to do the unthinkable: make brainy and expansive prog rock, while infusing it with punk, funk and even salsa. If you want to be blown away but not put off, you need to pick up Frances asap. Also, check out the single Frances The Mute, which was released in Europe. You can download it at a handfull of places, it really lends itself to the rest of the album
0425152251|4.0|I was steered to this book a couple of years ago while trapsing around Barnes and Noble.  My daughter's name is Sophie and I have always had an interest in Philosophy, so when I came across this book it immediately drew me in. <br /> <br />As others have indicated, this is a very introductory course in the history of Philosophy which leads you through 3000 years of philosophical development, growth, and evolution, and even provides a healthy overlapping of how Philosophy and Religion have been at times supporters and antagonists of each other.   <br /> <br />What is initially disturbing about this book occurs in the narrative portion where Sophie who is 4 weeks shy of her 15th birthday begins to receive with astonishing regularity correspondence from a much older man who has hand-picked her for this \\"crash course\\" in Philosophy.  There's no set-up as to why this has so abruptly begun, nor are we provided any real sense as to why Sophie would be so swept in into such a mature and profoud interaction with someone she has not met. <br /> <br />Yes, the narrative is weak and serves only to establish the scenes where the philosopher \\"teaches\\" the course at first through clandestine correspondence and then through similarly clandestine meetings with the philosopher.  However, the content within these teachings cannot be disregarded.  The author does a brilliant job at connecting us to the philosophical world, explaining who the key European players were and are and asking several essential philosophical questions for Sophie to consider which in turn compells us to consider them as well. <br /> <br />I enjoyed the book very much, overall, but feel that two books of greater enjoyment and punch could have been created had the author separated the course from the separate story of Sophie.  I don't think that one required the other.

B00007KWHN|5.0|With the advent of Steve Howe on guitar, Yes would begin the tranisition of a semi-psychedellic semi-folk band to a progressive rock band.  To be fair to original guitarist Peter Banks, he was a competent rhythm guitarist (his best moment is perhaps \\"Astral Traveller\\") but Howe's more versatile playing would force rings around Banks'.  This would also be keyboardist Tony Kaye's last album until 90125 (he was a great organist but lacked the technological knowhow that future keyboardists like Rick Wakeman, Patrick Moraz, Geoff Downes and Igor Khoroshev would possess).  The opener \\"Yours Is No Disgrace\\" opens with a bold introduction, the 1st verse does not appear until nearly 2 minutes into the song.  Howe plays different parts on different guitars and bassist Chris Squire plays bass almost like a 6-string guitar (his early influnences of Paul McCartney and John Entwistle would show up here).  Also, Jon Anderson would show more growth as a singer.  Tony Kaye's contributions on organ also fit in well (he uses a moog synthesizer at the end of the song).  Following is Steve Howe's acoustic guitar piece called \\"Clap.\\"  For many years, this song was pressed onto LP and CD as \\"The Clap,\\" much to the chagrin and resentment of Howe (I can just picture reviews \\"Get The Clap and many others on The Yes Album!\\").  Folk and blues are blended quite well here (there also exists a studio version of this song on this CD).  Following that is Yes' masterpiece \\"Starship Trooper,\\" which would feature Yes' signature key and tempo changes and Jon Anderson's semi-vague, sci-fi lyrics featured in the \\"Life Seeker\\" segment (\\"Speak to me of summer, long winters longer than time can remember,\\" \\"starship trooper, go sailing on by,\\" and \\"what I don't know, I have never heard\\" are examples).  Chris Squire also proved to be a great harmonist, you can hear him singing along with Anderson on the \\"Disillusion\\" segment.  Finally, Howe ends with a catchy riff played over and over again on the \\"Wurm\\" segment (I don't know if this influenced Lynyrd Skynyrd but their closing jam on \\"Free Bird\\" is reminiscent of this).  \\"I've Seen All Good People\\" became one of Yes' 1st \\"hits.\\"  The opening segment \\"Your Move\\" talks about a chess game \\"Move me onto any black square... don't surround yourself with yourself.\\"  There is also mention of several John Lennon/Beatles references \\"All we are saying is give peace a chance\\" and \\"send an instant kharma to me.\\"  The 2nd part features a catchy bass line by Squire and the line \\"I've seen all good people turn their heads each day so satisfied I'm on my way.\\"  The song closes with the chorus sung 2 keys lower each time (One disk jockey confesses that once while playing \\"I've Seen All Good People\\" on the radio, he turned off the phonograph at the fadeout of that song and the station manager reprimanded him!).  \\"A Venture\\" sounds like an outtake from earlier albums, it was the only song not featured in live performances.  \\"Peretual Change\\" is the last song on the original album.  The live version would give Bill Bruford an outlet for a drum solo.  Also included on this release are single versions of \\"Starship Trooper (Life Seeker)\\" and \\"Your Move.\\"  This album would point the direction where Yes was heading on future albums.
B00064AM6C|3.0|I agree with all the people praising the raw energy and emotion of this show. The performance of \\"Jolene\\" (a great song from Dolly Parton which shows country doesn't always suck) is manic. <br /> <br />However, let's not get carried away with calling Jack a great guitar player or Meg a great drummer. Having taught guitar (and played in Jazz/Funk bands) for 35 years Jack White is a terrible guitar player technically. It works for The White Stripes and gives them a raw edge but it's not musicianship. When you miss as many notes as Jack does, and you can count them by the dozens on this DVD, then it may be energetic/raw but it isn't good. Similarly, Meg doesn't as much drum as tap occasionally, Meg wont be confused with Gene Krupa or Neil Peart anytime soon. <br /> <br />Great music from poor musicians.

If they haven't seen it, I lend it to them.
